policies.title: Management of Technical Vulnerabilities
policies.policy_text: The organization shall establish and maintain a technical vulnerability management process to identify, evaluate, and remediate vulnerabilities in information systems. Vulnerability information must be obtained from multiple sources including security advisories, vendor notifications, and automated scanning (SAST, SCA, DAST). All systems and applications must be regularly assessed for vulnerabilities using industry-standard tools. Identified vulnerabilities must be classified according to risk level considering exploitability, business impact, and exposure. Remediation must be prioritized based on risk assessment results. Emergency patches must be applied within defined timeframes for critical vulnerabilities. A remediation tracking system must monitor progress and escalate overdue items. Post-remediation testing must verify successful mitigation without introducing new issues. Third-party dependencies must be continuously monitored and updated to non-vulnerable versions. Exceptions require documented risk acceptance and compensating controls.

implementation_requirements: Deploy automated vulnerability scanning (SAST, SCA, DAST) and integrate with ticketing
Subscribe to security advisory feeds (CVE/NVD, vendor bulletins)
Define SLAs for remediation by severity (e.g., Critical ≤7 days, High ≤14 days)
Maintain a vulnerability remediation database with ownership and due dates
Implement dependency update pipeline with automated PRs
Establish an exception process for accepted risks with compensating controls
verification_methods: Review vulnerability scan results and remediation SLAs
Audit patch deployment timelines and ownership
Verify dependency update cadence and SCA policy coverage
Check exception approvals and compensating control effectiveness

policies.title: Application Security Requirements
policies.policy_text: The organization shall define and implement security requirements throughout the application development lifecycle. Security requirements must be elicited during the design phase. Threat modeling must identify potential attack vectors. Secure architecture review must validate security controls. All code must undergo static analysis (SAST) to detect security flaws. Dynamic testing (DAST) must verify runtime security. Penetration testing must validate security before production release. Security regression testing must prevent reintroduction of vulnerabilities. Security metrics must track vulnerability trends. Continuous security monitoring must detect exploitation attempts. Secure coding standards must be enforced through automated checks. Code review must be mandatory before production deployment.

policies.title: Web Filtering and Secure Web Controls
policies.policy_text: The organization shall implement controls to protect against web-based threats. All web applications must undergo security testing including automated scanning and manual penetration testing. Input validation must be implemented on all user inputs to prevent injection attacks. Output encoding must prevent cross-site scripting. Content Security Policy headers must restrict resource loading. Security headers (HSTS, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options) must be configured. Rate limiting must prevent abuse. Session management must implement secure token generation and timeout controls. Web Application Firewall must provide defense-in-depth.

policies.title: Configuration Management for Third-Party Components
policies.policy_text: The organization shall manage configurations to ensure only approved and secure software versions are deployed. Third-party components must be inventoried and continuously monitored for known vulnerabilities. Only supported and non-vulnerable versions shall be used. Automated dependency updates must be enforced via CI/CD. Configuration baselines must be documented and version-controlled. Changes must be reviewed and tested before deployment. Emergency change procedures must exist for critical vulnerabilities. Deprecated or end-of-life components must be removed promptly.

policies.title: Use of Cryptography
policies.policy_text: The organization shall implement cryptographic controls to protect information confidentiality and integrity. Only strong, up-to-date cryptographic algorithms and key lengths shall be used. All network communications must use TLS with modern cipher suites. Token signing must use secure algorithms (e.g., RS256) with appropriate key rotation. Secrets must be managed via secure vaults, not hardcoded in source code. Key management must enforce rotation, access controls, and audit logging. Deprecated algorithms (e.g., MD5, SHA1, DES) are prohibited.

policies.title: Logging and Monitoring
policies.policy_text: The organization shall implement logging and monitoring to detect and investigate security events. Security-relevant events must be logged with sufficient detail. Logs must be protected against tampering and retained according to policy. Monitoring must correlate events across sources and alert on suspicious activity. Audit logs must be reviewed regularly. Findings must be investigated and escalated as incidents. Logging must not expose sensitive data.
